Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket just as I’m pulling on my hard hat. It’s Mom, right on time for our weekly call. I can almost hear her voice, warm and expectant, waiting to hear about my week, to tell me about Dad’s new hobby or the neighbor’s cat. I know how much these calls mean to her, how she worries if I miss even one. But the foreman’s whistle cuts through the morning air, sharp and urgent. The safety briefing is about to start, and everyone is already gathering by the trailer. Missing it isn’t an option—site rules are strict, and teamwork depends on everyone being present and alert. My fingers hover over the phone, heart thumping. I can’t be in two places at once, can’t be the attentive daughter and the reliable worker at the same time. The seconds tick by, and I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding I choose.
